text: "Total sports revenue (sportsbook and exchange) grew 1%. Sportsbook revenue increased 12%. While sportsbook staking was down 7% (declining 32% in H1 with growth of 20% in H2), net revenue margins increased 160 basis points year on year to 9.7%. Favourable sports results drove most of this uplift, accounting for approximately 140 basis points of the increase. Exchange and B2B revenue declined by 19% in 2020, but in H2 the exchange grew 3% as the sporting calendar normalised and US election markets generated good levels of customer interest."

elements.text: "Total sports revenue (sportsbook and exchange) grew 1%. Sportsbook revenue increased 12%. While sportsbook staking was down 7% (declining 32% in H1 with growth of 20% in H2), net revenue margins increased 160 basis points year on year to 9.7%. Favourable sports results drove most of this uplift, accounting for approximately 140 basis points of the increase. Exchange and B2B revenue declined by 19% in 2020, but in H2 the exchange grew 3% as the sporting calendar normalised and US election markets generated good levels of customer interest."

text: The exchange ecosystem needs a continual supply of fish. I don’t think it works if all that is left is the sharks. And I don’t believe that bookmaker hedging on Betfair is a particularly large source of (indirect) fish. Look at recent discussions around Smarkets and Matchbook who masquerade as exchanges but only let fish in. I don’t think they will be a realistic alternative if the Betfair exchange shut. We are relying on Betfair spending their marketing budget to get fish into the exchange and we are paying for that cost per acquisition through premium charge. But it’s not as simple as throwing money at advertising if the fish aren’t very price sensitive (which they aren't) and if the exchange is confusing for a newbie (which it is). You may not think the probability of the exchange closing is high but we are all familiar with expected value calculations and the negative value if it closes is extreme

elements.text: The exchange ecosystem needs a continual supply of fish. I don’t think it works if all that is left is the sharks. We are relying on Betfair spending their marketing budget to get fish into the exchange and we are paying for that cost per acquisition through premium charge. But it’s not as simple as throwing money at advertising if the fish aren’t very price sensitive (which they aren't) and if the exchange is confusing for a newbie (which it is). You may not think the probability of the exchange closing is high but we are all familiar with expected value calculations and the negative value if it closes is extreme

text: Some interaction between sportsbook and exchange would be interesting. Allow your resting orders on exchange to be matched with people placing bets on the sportsbook for perhaps a bump in the comission you pay. I'd imagine sportsbook flow is pretty benign (hence you pay comission to allow your orders to be matched with it), and people on sportsbook will most likely get price improvement on their bets Vs the displayed sportsbook price (that's the incentive for them)

text:
Probably multiple factors (just guessing here):

1. At the moment people are probably running out of cash frankly, given how many are on no or reduced incomes
2. The exchange goes down quite a bit and that puts people off (negative coverage on twitter, youtube etc)
3. Seemingly a huge push from sports books to get people to place ACCA's (every other add seems to be pushing one) and misleading people into thinking they offer better value
4. Some people might perceive it to be too 'professional' or complex (just speculating there)

elements.text: Probably multiple factors (just guessing here):
At the moment people are probably running out of cash frankly, given how many are on no or reduced incomes
The exchange goes down quite a bit and that puts people off (negative coverage on twitter, youtube etc)
Seemingly a huge push from sports books to get people to place ACCA's (every other add seems to be pushing one) and misleading people into thinking they offer better value
Some people might perceive it to be too 'professional' or complex (just speculating there)

text: Can anyone confirm how long the delay is between placing a bet and it being returned in the order stream? I know the bet has to be processed, which obviously creates a delay. Reason I ask is because one of my strategies is double-betting on some selections. What's the best way to avoid this? Local cache on placement?

elements.text: Can anyone confirm how long the delay is between placing a bet and it being returned in the order stream? I know the bet has to be processed, which obviously creates a delay. Reason I ask is because one of my strategies is double-betting on some selections. What's the best way to avoid this? Local cache on placement?

text: I wait 750ms + bet delay, and I've never had issues. I could probably tune it lower than 750ms, but never had a reason to

elements.text: I wait 750ms + bet delay, and I've never had issues. I could probably tune it lower than 750ms, but never had a reason to

text: The best way is probably as you said, a local in flight tracker. Add orders to the tracker on placement. The strategy can then check the tracker to see if it has any orders in flight and choose not to place any more. When the order comes in from the order stream you remove it from the in flight tracker.

elements.text: The best way is probably as you said, a local in flight tracker. Add orders to the tracker on placement. The strategy can then check the tracker to see if it has any orders in flight and choose not to place any more. When the order comes in from the order stream you remove it from the in flight tracker.
